name: First Schedule
description: The First Schedule lists all States and Union Territories (UTs) of India and defines their territorial boundaries. It is divided into two parts: Part A lists the names of States along with details of their territories; Part B lists Union Territories and their respective territorial extents. This schedule also includes provisions for altering state boundaries, creating new states, or modifying existing territories through parliamentary legislation under Articles 2, 3, and 4.

name: Second Schedule
description: The Second Schedule deals with the salaries, allowances, privileges, and emoluments of key constitutional authorities. These include: the President, Vice-President, Governors of States, Speakers and Deputy Speakers of the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies, Chairpersons and Deputy Chairpersons of the Rajya Sabha and State Legislative Councils, Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts, and the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG). The schedule contains several parts (A to I), each addressing a different constitutional office and its financial entitlements.

name: Third Schedule
description: The Third Schedule provides the official forms of oaths or affirmations that must be taken by various constitutional authorities before assuming office. These include Union Ministers, Members of Parliament (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha), State Ministers, Members of State Legislatures, the Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts, and the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG). The schedule ensures uniformity and constitutional allegiance through standardized oath forms under Articles 75(4), 99, 124(6), 188, and others.

name: Fourth Schedule
description: The Fourth Schedule specifies the allocation of seats for each State and Union Territory in the Rajya Sabha (Council of States). The number of seats is based on population and may be altered by Parliament. This schedule ensures proportional representation of states in the upper house, balancing federal principles with demographic realities. It operates under Articles 4 and 80.

name: Fifth Schedule
description: This schedule contains the provisions relating to the administration and control of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes in any state except those covered under the Sixth Schedule. It includes: (a) declaration of Scheduled Areas; (b) establishment of Tribes Advisory Councils for states with significant tribal populations; (c) powers of the Governor to make regulations for the peace and good governance of Scheduled Areas; (d) protection of tribal land and resources. It operates under Article 244(1) to ensure tribal welfare and autonomy.

name: Sixth Schedule
description: The Sixth Schedule provides a unique system of autonomous administration for tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram. It establishes Autonomous District Councils and Regional Councils with legislative, administrative, and judicial powers. These councils can make laws on topics such as land, forests, water, village administration, inheritance, marriage, and social customs. The schedule aims to protect tribal identity and self-governance under Article 244(2) and Article 275(1).

name: Seventh Schedule
description: The Seventh Schedule distributes legislative powers between the Union and State governments through three lists: (1) Union List – subjects on which only Parliament can legislate (e.g., defence, foreign affairs, banking, railways); (2) State List – subjects on which only state legislatures can legislate (e.g., police, public order, agriculture); (3) Concurrent List – subjects on which both Parliament and state legislatures can legislate (e.g., education, marriage and divorce, forests). Parliament has overriding authority in case of conflict on Concurrent List matters. It operates under Articles 246 and 248.

name: Eighth Schedule
description: The Eighth Schedule lists the officially recognized languages of India. Originally containing 14 languages, it now includes 22 languages after various constitutional amendments (such as the 21st, 71st, and 92nd amendments). The schedule empowers the government to promote and develop these languages and plays a key role in language policy, education, and government communication. It operates under Articles 344 and 351.

name: Ninth Schedule
description: The Ninth Schedule contains laws related primarily to land reforms and agrarian restructuring, including abolition of the zamindari system. Laws placed in this schedule were originally immune from judicial review under Article 31B to protect them from being challenged for violating fundamental-rights. However, the Supreme Court’s judgment in the I.R. Coelho (2007) case clarified that Ninth Schedule laws are subject to judicial review if they violate the basic structure of the Constitution.

name: Tenth Schedule
description: Commonly known as the Anti-Defection Law, this schedule provides rules for disqualification of Members of Parliament (MPs) and State Legislatures (MLAs) on the grounds of defection. It defines when voluntary giving up of party membership or voting against party directions results in disqualification. It also defines the roles of the Speaker/Chairperson as the decision-making authority in defection cases. Inserted by the 52nd Amendment Act, 1985 and strengthened by the 91st Amendment Act, 2003.

name: Eleventh Schedule
description: The Eleventh Schedule lists 29 subjects that outline the powers, responsibilities, and functions of Panchayati Raj Institutions (rural local governments). These subjects include agriculture, rural housing, drinking water, poverty alleviation, rural electrification, roads, health, women and child development, social welfare, and maintenance of community assets. Introduced by the 73rd Amendment Act, 1992, it aims to decentralize governance and promote grassroots democracy.

name: Twelfth Schedule
description: The Twelfth Schedule lists 18 subjects related to the powers and responsibilities of Urban Local Bodies (Municipalities). Key subjects include urban planning, regulation of land use, slum improvement, public health, water supply, sanitation, fire services, urban forestry, protection of environment, and provision of urban amenities. Introduced by the 74th Amendment Act, 1992, this schedule strengthens urban governance and decentralization.
